values:
I'm done with romance.

I'm done with feeling.

I'm done with dreaming.

I'm done with love.

I'm done with ideals.

I'm done with hoping.
 
Nihilism is the only true path to sanity.

I wish I was a nihilist.

I wish I really was done with all that shit.

From Wikipedia: Lilith is a female Mesopotamian night demon believed to harm male children. She is often identified as the first wife of Adam and sometimes thought to be the mother of all incubi and succubi, a legend that arose in the Middle Ages. Lilith is also sometimes considered to be the paramour of Satan. In medieval legend, a succubus is a demon which takes the form of a female to seduce men in dreams to have sexual intercourse. They draw energy from the men to sustain themselves, often until the point of exhaustion or death of the victim. From mythology and fantasy, Lilith and the Lilin (Jewish), Lilitu (Sumerian) and Rusalka (Slavic) were succubi. And you know what? I don't care. I guess that's how it works.

This week I've had a family of five thousand living in my stomach.

The summer thus far has been a Classic Life Experience, for the most part, a series of spiraling ups and downs (but mostly ups) that have spun me into a mostly happily confused frenzy.

But an emphasis on "confused."

Emily was done with me quickly; her new social circle made the thirty minute drive to Montevallo a hassle, especially for someone who probably wasn't that interested in the first place.  Thus my world became different.  Montevallo became infinitely more interesting - once one exits the high school world and visits the world of university students and young adults, one realizes quickly that one has misjudged this quaint little town.

Also previously misconceived was the size of the dating pool here.  And as we know, with the introduction of any attractive female with even the slightest bit in common with me comes the near-instantaneous onset of self-generated intense feeling on my part, thus several co-workers became the unknowing recipients of a trademark John Paul Crush, the kind that simmers in my brain for days and goes nowhere because I'm terrified.

However, the genesis of the week found me with a small amount of courage, and Monday began with my intentions secured: I would, that night, have secured a one-on-one social engagement with the girl I had my sights set on, a co-worker.  A bit after getting off work myself and mowing the lawn, I ventured to Eclipse with the intention of being charming.

In my mind, a small globe had recently come to a place of balance.  My thoughts had somewhat leveled, and this globe no longer spun out of control as it once had.  I walked out of the front door at Eclipse, and sat down on the porch.  As I did this, a hand gripped the sphere and spun it, like a top, at light speed.

At first, this dizzying sensation was sourced in blatant and unexpected female attention, from an interesting one, and it seemed in order that perhaps my recent bout with feeling undesirable would come to a close, even for a brief moment.

She invited me back to her apartment, abruptly, so we could show one another our various artworks.  Feeling self-conscious but excited, I excused myself with her from the porch and drove her home.

Then a new chapter began, a dream sequence.  In the following days, all my numerous crushes and my frustrations with Emily were wiped out in one fell swoop.  

I began to understand something I had forgotten... that electric charge between my finger and her neck, that atomic explosion contained in a pair of good-night hugs.  That ache in my gut that won't let me eat.  That delirious, terrifying happiness.  That feeling of life not even seeming real anymore.

And then all of this other stuff: the horrifyingly complete honesty, the continuing revelations of my darker secrets, and the feeling of being understood, the feeling that someone else is thinking a lot of the exact same weird shit that I'm thinking.

As tradition holds, this is terrifying because I don't know what she's thinking about the situation while I know exactly what I'm thinking.  But it's also terrifying because it's new and it's wonderful, and I'm not having to convince myself of anything or question what I'm feeling.

So it goes.  The dream sequence continues; tonight was a surreal nightmare at work and elsewhere.  Who knows what the morning will bring.  Who ever knows what the morning will bring.

Again I tried to teach Mikey, who is almost done with first grade, how to play chords on the guitar.  His hands are small and he wraps them too tightly around the neck every time, pressing down unintentional strings and usually botching the chords he's trying to play.  However, he's clearly a natural. / Last night I saw kids on the playground with toy guns in the atmosphere, shooting stars at one another.  I have no wishes, I just hope for things that I'm not going to get, but that's what keeps things exciting.  I don't write plans, I write plays that have very little possibility of ever being staged. / And so she painted herself into the tapestry with the details to be filled in later.  I wrapped my small hands around the guitar neck to write something pretty, but my fingers only went flat and pressed down the wrong strings. / This is a journal entry, and something is moving inside of me, either to burrow a hole deep inside and inspire semi-permanent warmth or to exit with explosive force of a bullet that generates pretty melodies and the right time to change to the major seventh. / I've got me a bad case of the Stockholm Syndrome.  No, don't warn me.  I know it's wrong.  Summer's what you make it, but I'll believe what I want to believe - and I do believe.  I do believe.  But I'm trying not to, just drinking gallon after gallon of formaldehyde.  But self-preservation will clearly only kill me.

The spectres on the television dance and spit color around the room, more fascinating color than is to be found reflected in my eyes.  Tomorrow the sun will pour itself through the trees like fingers in my hair while I run away from the arrows you shot in my side.  I dug clay from the lake to make bricks and poured cement so we could build a tiny shelter and I could sleep beside your body and at least dream about keeping our faces close. / And once when we sat together the sun warmed my lips and curled their corners before the black clouds opened and froze them, building thick rivers on our cheeks that kept us cold and invisible.  I sucked my fingers for comfort and imagined pretty secrets woven between us, digging their sewing-needles into my stomach and finding a home there.  The needles pulled tight and I awoke in a room full of skylights and paper lamps, and I twined my warm arms with the person next to me, pretending the songs the sleeping needles sang were laced with truth while laying awake and scratching them across the rings on black plastic. / There's a girl that lives in my stomach who taps at the walls and escapes on occasion.  She wraps her hands around me when she leaves, and I can smile and hum. And once I even kissed her, kissed her like I was a boy burning warm and terrified.

I built a field of glass grass that glows blue from reflecting the sky and sent you an invitation to shrink with me and explore the cerulean blades like they're the towering buildings making canyons in the city.  When the rain comes, we'll burrow warm homes in manmade caves and put matches in the ground for torches, and they'll burn to the ground and we'll heat our skin for blankets.  In the morning we'll smile and roll our eyes, and I'll exit to hack twigs with hatchets so we can burn holes in the ice. / Foxes flew airplanes in between the mountains and sent streams of fire towards the cabins built half-underground, and everyone within bolted for the cellar.  All the plants in their yards caught light and slowly melted into a new reflecting pool before the ocean rose and broke the lake into sand.  The foxes landed and nosed the alien landscape, but couldn't smell anything and fell asleep.  The people from the cabins emerged from their cellars and sheltered the foxes, for they meant little harm. / Spinning on scratched black vinyl floors, we crushed our insides and grinned with abandon.  If our bodies burn to the ground, at least we'll go happy, and while pinkish comets streak the sky we'll rest on a pier by the water when the wind pushes ripples across.  And we'll see the orange in our eyes and squint to keep each other out, but as long as our pupils signal in morse code with their fingers in your hair, we'll stay quiet, and smile to spite them.

Dressing in giant's clothes and drinking bottles of white wine, we crawled on the balconies to admire the canopies, painting frozen frames on the jar where I keep my secrets.  There were video game lights playing on kids' faces behind the lake where the adults toured their ex-playground, laughing harder than they ever remembered.  The silver moon stays in the lining of the clouds, who keep the light away from the earth. / I had little brothers and sisters once, and we pressed our wrists together to feel our pulses moving.  Watch our fingers twitch atop metal forks, whack them against shingles to hear them sing, and marvel at how the ringing harmonies oscillate around our grown-up ears, painting photographs of obscure fairy tales, sugary lies we can keep wrapped up and frozen. / When the teenage dancers thaw, we'll shut up and throw ourselves on a dark bed to swallow boxes of cough drops so our throats go numb.  Tell the little boy at the window there's little to worry about, and he can be slow and gentle with bent arms to hide his contented sighs.  Take photographs, little tourists, photographs to laminate on jars that will stir saltwater when your children flip through yellowed pages. / Let's admit our secrets so we can enjoy them.  If you know how to smile, if you remember how, then I can telephone a magician who can wave a twig and fix the smile wider for good.  'How did he do that?' A good magician never tells his secrets, though, he only hints at them.

We'll hide in the shadows until morning, and the ghosts of small animals will haunt us in our dreams.  They creep up by our ears and speak in pale blue voices, telling us all the tiny things that crawl under their skin.  These are the animals we whisper about when we falter at the door, when one kid lets his brain wander too far into nomansland, creating a cold parallel universe to serve as a surrogate fantasy world. / I crawled into air ducts with you alien faces and pressed my face close against each of the girls, out of curiosity.  Here we are hiding, I'd say, just a couple of us humans trying things on for size and wondering what it's like to study the way things grow on other planets.  I love the way your clouds swirl in your eyes, I'd mutter charmingly, but sometimes it makes it hard to see in.  One of these days, I'll find a chemical in a spraybottle and gently wipe away the thick atmosphere so I can understand what's quiet on the surface. / And O (name), he cried, how I can rest like a boy on your shoulder.  How I can mate a comforter and discomfort.  How I can make the pink worms trapped in my face sing about chasms and the tunnels they're digging away from warmth, where I found fire and kept my hands red and warm.  Once I stuck my hand all the way in and pulled it out, blackened.  I let it heal and kept my distance, but I still wonder what the flames feel like in my hands.  Warmth is the comfort of sleepy arms in a bed at night, and I could stand the thermostat at two hundred.

Sunlight make the grass gold before the shade, brush my face when I rush by the low point in the rollercoaster.  I'd dance among the penguins with you, but I'm no bird these days, and the boys in their black ties keep the doors to the ballroom shut.  In the future I'll take pins and needles in my suit for you and sew pockets for us to hide our hands in. / We sat on brown carpet spinning records with our heads spinning and the light quiet.  We can dance, here where our feet are lighter, and swing around and collapse on the floor with broken legs, laughing at the wrinkles by the eyes of the other.  Speak only in whispers near ears, the things that aren't allowed to cut the air.  And blackbirds swoop from the ceiling and pour from the fireplace until the sparklers in the chimney ignite and the room is filled with flaming birds casting shadows that jerk and dance and the room becomes kaleidoscopic when we spin again.  / If I cover my face with my comforter, I achieve invincibility.  At night I leap from star to star with my hands casting shadowpuppets on strange planets, repopulating with butterflies and rabbits, painting impossible scenes on the clouds and oceans and the creatures on feet beneath.  'What a strange eclipse dancing in the sky,' the television says, and the astronomers with their telescopes etch fantasies on their lenses that blossom with fingers in starlight.

Come on, let's watch fountains sputter like broken sprinklers and dance between them in the summertime.  Let's go to work on waterslides and grin so wide from my ear to yours that people in the stands wonder who we are, waving ourselves to the bottom of the ocean.  We've wired oxygen tanks to our lungs, so let's get hypersaturated and sink to the bottom, dizzy and sleepy, and we can sit on black basalt, lost in conversation, with fish pushing tiny currents that tickle our faces. / And the sun will strike the trees on the shore and paint black fronds on the sidewalks and clothes of strangers wandering through gardens holding hands, two by two on benches separated by hedges that whisper secrets that children know and forget on their way to the omniscience of the grown-up world.  Food smells waft out of beachside windows and paint the air warm red-yellows when the sun comes in from the side over the water, and kids with orange faces careen down the dunes to their unsafe home by the water to delight their senses until high tide, and then the sea spray will tickle their eyelids and cause sneezing fits.  But they'll only laugh and squint at each other, fascinated. / And so the story goes, page by page, until it's buried in sediment and the fingers in our brain can't turn anything more.  And oh well, we'll sing anyway about the strands of light that hit us and make the glass around our faces sparkle.

My back is soaked like it's raining saltwater in the heat off of my wet shoulders.  Wake up, baby in my bed, quit napping, and look at the beads on your forehead.  Rise and run from midnight to sunup and sleep in the ground's sweat when the old sun puts new light in your eyes, another nap, and remember the dark parts of good dreams when you stir during the day, and the glowing scenes will serve as lullabies when you soak your pillow at night. / I checked on the kids and they had sewn their fingers together to prove that pain is only a trick played by electric animals that press the right buttons in the skulls of the gullible.  'We can ignore it,' they sang.  'We are baby logicians, even when our fingers untwine.'  Logic is only a trick played by computers run by the electric animals, and fingers long sewn make for red hands upon separation. / All the clouds are misshapen friends who dissolved and tried to touch the sun in the morning.  On happy occasions they weep for weeks, watching the stage-play below, remembering their quiet lives as tragedians, and if only they'd felt that gold on their skin to satisfaction beforehand.  Now the sun crawls on their backs and kicks them to remind the crying ants underneath them to remember the temperature, because otherwise they'd build hills to the atmosphere and melt into infinite sets of white masses hurtling across the surface of the world.  Unfortunately, they are no more satisfied as clouds than the clouds themselves, who were no more satisfied as ants.

Open up two chests to watch, and see which one bleeds a little more.  I tied my veins in square knots to wither my heart and protect myself, and sang old songs while I fumbled behind my ribs to pass the time and keep me from going cold.  Should have shot myself numb.  Shouldn't have left forceps in the cavity; I'll need those to pull out a miracle on the week's end. / We birds built clothes-nests in enormous plastic bins and tunneled to the core to spend the night.  In the morning we'll be shopped through, wriggling merchandise, and taken together in plastic sacks, thrown into a mysterious home with violent children and heartstopping sunsets. / I know how the gold stays in the glass.  It melted in with the sand and dropped streaks across your eyelids that sent the sunlight, yellow-white, dripping down my bare walls and puddling on the carpet.  And when we can't see anymore we'll put our faces together and make believe that we have no wishes, like procrastinating reactants.  One day a scientist will shake us awake and hold flames to our throats so we'll yell all our secrets with lights out and fire dancing on our twisted legs.  'Stand and arrest denial,' and the magician drifts away in thin smoke so we can dance with the fires on our hideous feet.  And now we won't sit and wonder where innocence went, when we can press our faces close and still feel innocent.

If it ain't broke, don't break it.  The bushes are lighter at the tips, but only in the early spring.  I danced with acquaintances in dormitory tunnels last night, a clustered maze of confused post-adolescents stretching their long fingers at one another, greener at the tips. / Heat lightning in the bedrooms while the clouds pour themselves outside.  I've been convinced to open the blinds; better to marvel at the beautiful doldrums than to wonder if I should marvel at holograms.  But the winds billow all the same, faster than light, like cold wet fingers dragging through the paint.  Your eyes nearly blew off your face, and I held my mouth just so to prevent such a tragedy, or at least to keep everyone safe from the squall.  Come on outside in white cloaks, we'll be sailboats and run across the lake.  The children with their parents scream, smile, and point, and mom and dad pretend to explain, lost in their own mystification. / I carved a flute into my arm, and now I can play lullabies by blowing across my fingers.  I have to bend them just so, and I need training, but I still sit on my bed and trill molten melodies out of my elbow.  I'd keep my fingers crossed that they would reach you, but crossed fingers only carve dissonance. / If you want sweet, I'll throw sugars at your feet and we'll lay on towels, licking our fingers and pressing them into the sand.  If you want to smile, keep your eyes closed and the things that make you happy with you in a glass safe, floating on the water, with no combination or key.

I woke up this morning with my eyelids sewn shut.  Keep the blinds drawn and the screen on, admire the light in the projection.  We're only in this for the money.  A three-year-old jumps on the couch and asks his father to draw him some conclusions.  'Draw your own conclusions.' 'But all I have is crayons!'  Tack it to the doorframe and smile at it when you walk by. / The beetles were all dead, shed their husks by the sidewalks on the walk home, crunching underneath my feet when my attention diverted.  They're only shells, after all, crisp meat for the soil stuck to the sole of my shoe.  But I keep my crisp outer shell tacked firmly to the feet of giant strangers regularly.  I keep pulling blankets around my body under the streetlights, because it's perfect at nine o'clock when the sun's nesting and I forget adulthood, but it's colder at night, and I think about rolling my sleeves down. / I'm still alright at tracing, but my hands shake when I'm nervous and the bones fall out of their sockets.  I carry around stiff gloves to remedy the problem.  Every day there's a minute where I can see straight up through a glass tunnel piercing the sky and look straight into the core of the sun, and before my eyes burn out I can see everything I've ever wanted to see clearly, like waking up inside a dream.

I'm clumsy like a seventh-grade dancer.  Keep twirling on feet and saving yourself at the last minute, friend, and hold your eyes closed tight, because this one might be a doozy.  I'll brace myself for a few more swings at the face, because they sparkle like miracles in basements when the sun finally comes out. / There's a girl smiling on the screen behind my eyes, and I keep hoping it's an accurate representation.  I'm bad with proportion.  Icicles melt in the summertime, and none of them will be driving steel spikes through my chest.  Instead we'll sit in the trees and listen to the insects' hum and the crickets painting an asystemic symphony.  Perhaps we'll tear a few walls down to kill time and wind up nested dangerously in old blankets that smell like the floor in the forest.  Maybe we could build a fort from the blankets and wall ourselves inside to generate a different planet filled with better blues and greens.  Maybe it's just summer, but they look newer already.  The leaves have been taken to laundry, and have returned bright from their bracing vacation. / Maybe once the co-stars relax, the animal in his stomach will crawl out and devour him whole.  At this point, though, it's a given.  Battling it is useless: it's got its teeth in the actors' shoulders, and there's nary a method to shake it. / I've got problems, but with problems like these, who needs easy living?

I can feel my skeleton turning to marshmallow, back to the powdered bones of other animals.  It's a thrill, but a terrifying one, balancing one leg on the edge, cutting off the body, and sending it sailing down into the questionable bliss of a free-fall. / My rhinoceros has a marshmallow horn, he told me, and it won't hurt me.  'Sweet and white.  There is no sting.  Hair and sugar, like coals and diamonds.'  You can say whatever to me, and I'll listen with my eyes closed.  Fantasies aren't supposed to have pretty faces.  But God made my eyelids out of cellophane, and so ignoring it or putting a dark mask around it are failed options. / But the clandestine operations of doctors have left needles in my arms half-empty, pumping a strange, beautiful drug.  Who knows how much juice is left.  If we're preservationists, let's save ourselves the hassle of immediate withdrawal.  This is the marrow, this is the brilliant promise of idealist adolescents brought to fruition.  It happens to no one; let's keep it out of the landfills.  Sure, it's emotional opulence, and we should prevent conspicuous waste.  Pull the needles out, and we bleed for months; we're left with what-ifs and bruises.  I wear goggles and earmuffs when I jump in front of trains, but we could probably board if we leap at the right time. / Connections this fierce are, by definition, inconvenient.  Let's make no particular plans.  The most convenient future is written by the inconvenient present, and sometimes the inconvenient things are the best ones.

The air smells like cracked machines, that ozone smell.  All of the gears are turning and they're getting nowhere; maybe they're rustier than I thought.  The machine is wondering, too, what's happening, and what it can do to adjust paramaters to avoid failure. / I go for walks at night and I see the way the sky is lit up behind the mountains, a dull glowing purplish-orange, and the clouds are spelling out the first few sentences of some grand sprawling narrative.  The writer doesn't know what's going to happen next, he just rolls with the punches, because all he's done is set the characters in motion, and then writing down how they interact with one another.  It makes for a compelling drama when he's mustered two characters as fascinating as these, and the audiences in the auditoriums will doubtlessly love to shoot their eyes at this grand fantasy. / Waking up on Sunday morning is burned in permanently, the kind that makes your stomach buzz.  Sometimes it feels like the ol' ticker's gonna give out, or something else.  Let's hold a press conference no one will remember in the morning.  We get all the questions answered but forget the answers as soon as we remember them. / I don't even care if I'm throwing up carrots or riding a nuclear weapon.  I'm going to start writing comedies now, where the teenagers talking on the bed just keep talking without the tragedy soaking up all of the blood.  I'd love to see the audience leaving the auditorium with grins on their faces, after all.

Oh, what the fuck; I can sit here and burn hours away on the internet.  Last night I lived in auditoriums again, but I'm always in the audience, and it's a packed house.  I wonder why I'm shying away from the stage.  If I'm writing journal entries, it means one of two things: I'm a bird or I'm a tiger.  Once, when I was younger, I found a way to cross-breed the two, and the photograph of that animal's lived on my mantle for years.  Birds and tigers only die, after all. / But I've had small fires burning up and out of somewhere in my stomach for a few days now, and all of a sudden there's fire all in my bloodstream, going all around my body, turning me into bees when I step out of certain doors.  I keep telling myself that it's bad, and the logical side of me is yelling and shooting knives into my stomach and whatever methods of defense he can muster, but he's fighting a losing battle again. / I take that back, it isn't logic, it's emotional self-preservation (or, as normal people say, "fear.") / I keep digging holes up around the yard, hoping that somewhere buried beneath it all will be some small piece of sense, some small chunk of truth.  Either that or I'll jump in a hole and take out a tiny computer and crunch numbers until it spits out everything I want to know on a tiny piece of paper, and then I can take the evidence to the neighbors. / Will they be surprised?  I keep signs in my windows, and they aren't blind.  I've even seen signs in their windows, but they always say things that could be ambiguous, even though they're relatively straightforward.  I can't take anything at face value, or I'll wind up embarrassing myself. / But after all, what's embarrassment but fresh fodder for more music to record and never release to anyone?  There's nothing terribly noble about being the Fool, but then again, what sort of noble am I?

Wake and shake the sheets,
And then bury my face in the bookcrease
For a quarter of a day,
Until the closing doors of the liquor store
Dragged me away five pages early,
Because the party must go on.
Big glass jug of hot berried water,
Twenty-five won't fill the tank,
And it's dinnertime.
I kept the wayward cheese from my wrath,
And I drank another gallon of tomatillos.
Took another budget haul from the shot,
Took another fifty's worth of food.
And so we drink and drink,
And no friends show. So we pull out the tablet
To etch the bizarre into the screen.

I am a machine with the one that sews.
So finish the hard parts and run home.
Watch my tank strain to drop Erin off,
And then let lunch slip my mind.
Documentary documentary, I write rhymes intermittently
And rush off to shop, and run to K
Two apples and a quart of chunky.
Let's cut up the kitchen floor.
Backsplash done, try to shim the sink unit
But the saw disagrees with everyone.
Then Erin and I laid on my bed
And I let the scorpions out so we could play with them
Erin looked at them quizzically,
And they stung me in the face for awhile
Before burrowing back into their hole.
Rehearsal remains an absurd paradise
With ceiling sacks and back massages,
Name-dropping the gravy donkey
And dancing the melting ferret.
What's she look like pregnant?
Those are sharp tails, but I'll tough it out.

Class fast, late and I'm a dick.
Sweat stinks me on the way,
Scorpions rattling around.
Touch the machines, run through them, got it.
Pettiness to film, and we both bite back the tugs at eyes
At K I spiel a training session,
Patching the whole operation
Late to Japanese, mind whirling, unexpected ride,
But still late.
The McAlister digging commences afterward,
Years upon years of furniture wearing sweater-thick dust
Set up the set, level level.
I'm just wild about saffron rice.
There's still a whole can of worms at rehearsal
Fun worms, very fun worms.
The family in the house starts growing,
And I can smell myself weeping its conclusion already.
We pull our middle fingers from our loins.
A rat-tat-chat-chat with the various,
And when Erin's clean we start to feel better.
But Dream Noir makes everyone uneasy.

Thread flows through guides, and we all watch again.
Lunch passes through lazy mouths, and I flee the scene,
To watch emperors and ex-warriors blanche West
Shake a few spiders out of my brain,
And humbly beg Heston and Welles to touch me.
I slice up garlic and ginger root
And throw my face into the mist,
Before Samuel French introduces himself to the company,
And all those sneaky salesmen keep creeping.
I can smell the salt in my eyes already.
A toothbrushing fiasco keeps the bed steady and the pillows wet
But only for a bit.
I'm telling those Macbeth scorpions their lease is up.

Frantic sampler fuckups avant classe
Of no import, we learn the secrets of machines
And speak of frames and thieves.
Brain begins browning at lunch
And sours further through documentaries
Sky's got poison in the white clouds.
We fold century-old drops, dusting the stage with pigment
Untying and retying until chased off.
Moonchildren audition flips with no hitch
Samuel French and his Hawaiian sausage wolf.
I slap a patch into the sampler and run.
At the ranch, there are three hours of verbal torture
Where our eyes rain the bed
But then he speaks of the secrets of machines
Of the information sponge
And we breathe easy enough for spaghetti and television.
When our limbs entangle it feels like singing.

Ankle-deep in hairy shower-water.
Free samples available, oh snap!
Mine went backward.
The Viper and I flow Bazinities for VH
Then Erin and I introduce violent discussions:
Long-form photography.
Yagi's screen follies follow, in Docu-Japan,
After roving a planet packed with giant butterflies.
In the Italian frame, we resist analyzing QVC
And someone's bike gets stolen.
Before choking on pervasive malaise,
There are p-cakes for dinner
And Chris and Tetsuya, at my request,
Whip us off to surrogate Sweden,
Where we meander through streets with a pretend purpose
While the diabetics dig for hot dogs.
When in Japan, every hard drug is good once.
In the Eagle, hipsters meet contradancers,
And I meet beer and fries
(A jerk shrimp/chicken pasta dish makes an appearance at the table)
Erin and I ramp up before we psych-explode
In shit-hot guitars and drum solos.
Lulled home, we stroll back to K and collapse after sewing.
Oh my alien friends, oh my alien faces.

Sunday romp, off with a bang!
New veggie wads n' muffins at lunch
And the discipline to read English
Or jump immediately to video games.
Quad-improv slithers and creeps through the theatre
Sweaty and smelling of brown sugar,
Intoning, 'clomp, clomp, rustle, squirt.'
Copyright 2005.
English pops up and eats itself,
And Erin and I rush to the store
So our dreams of opening a pub in K can come true.
Our restaurant-home dinner stays on us for hours,
A miracle from the god of near-fish n' chips.
Slurp up the final few strands of English
And swim until I drift
To where I'm still wandering, 
A surrealist road trip along back alleyways,
The same huge dark rooms,
The same alien faces.

A room day, after twelve hours, a romp seems key.
I slowly defeat my 'juken review while Erin dances on the bed with a book.
Then demon-Annie threw her disgusting parties
And Daddy Warbucks played along note-by-note.
Time siphoned off, suctioned, disappeared,
A year of real life as a fondly-remembered dream.
You must not know who I is:
It's 'Pos up in your taint
And potatoes in elevators.
Nerves twitched till dinner,
I'm no hypercritical bastard,
And the falafels know it.
Josh and Anne swing towards the apartment
With Office videos, which play for 1:30 until my eyelids strangely drooop
And they're off to thin air in an instant.
The porn stars are filled with HIV.
Back up to p-cakes and fake snakes,
Put things on hold to patch another leaky face.
Tap the TV, running commentary,
But both of us drift away...
Somewhere I'm looking for gas, and it's night all the time.
Images keep flickering past of the black sky,
And doors in some old house.
There are all these friends I never knew there.

Awake from an easy long sleep into a light breeze
Smiling at the clouds hanging on the afternoon.
We keep the crowds in stitches and finish the hard parts
Stay a bit longer...
Erin's off to work on the other end of campus,
So I drive.  Then the last few bites down the gullet,
To Cathoric school, lural areas, ware nabe ni toji-buta.
Shoes today, but I worry about Shorts: The Return.
No matter. Cut black straps and serge forward,
But not with Wink's skill.
Tedium = entertainment.  And so shall the crew rule.
'Official weekend.'
The hunter-gatherers disperse for liquors and dinner
Ingles presents the square-faced white-haired man
Accidentally inciting riots among two customers.
Falafels kick grease in our faces, and we kick teeth into theirs.
The Nijja flailed through the kitchen
And the Viper and I retraced our steps through Europe.
*pop*
Ghost Doggin' the stubbornest drunken Movie Nite attendees,
No one will finish, because Erin and I have to nap on the bathroom floor,
And in my dreams we watched the walls full of bullets sparkle in the morning

On the paths through the village, the day felt heavy.
Muslims get stitches. Talks about Eddie run short.
Out to burrito, back to Japan,
The pot and the pig.
Quick, to shop, flip-flop.
Alan and I to K, Alan reports on the Nizz.
I perched on a ladder, stole foam and sexualized the saw tables.
Got to squirm Allison's audition.
Open packed house, grated at the door
Led new ones about through buddy systems
Frozen French's mustard to drink.
Afterward, two celebrities melted into high-schoolers
So I broke her legs and put her leaky face into my chest
Singing songs about quiet.

Hah,
Woke up at nine, for class at ten, of course...
But no, 'twas convocation. Erin and I stayed at the theatre
I played darts unusually well.
Back in the hole, an emergency arose and fell.
More Japan; a bit late, but no matter.
Lunched after. Edward Scissorhandsed after.
Been there, done that. Next up: naked mole rat.
Fell asleep with my face on Erin's shoulder
So I didn't make dinner. Frozen burritos
And hummus instead. Erin and I discussed
The lingering taste later.
And then off to Improv! I'm late.
Allison's back dies off and she plays scenes from the floor.
'Punch him!'
In K, play laugh-at-things with Adam, touch the vapor,
Walk the village, misty sidewalk-lights and errant sprinklers,
Lead her back when she goes blind.

I finished a new song today, track 01 from the Real Frogs LP THE MAYFLY MAN.

I am safety, hour three

Don't you remember me, Helene?
Yesterday I had Vinegar, Clean & Clear astringent, and Tide laundry detergent in my hair for two hours because the hot water ran out. Man, I do some weird shit when the hot water runs out.

Were were were were werwe

NOT SO EASY, THOUGH!

This STATEMENT is false!!!

So I took a nap this afternoon, because I felt like shit in so many ways.  However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that I dreamt quite vividly, remembered all of it, and it was deliciously absurd!

I'm not sure I remember the chronology exactly, but here's the way I THINK it went:

Meghan shows up at my house and says she wants to get drunk, so I'm like "OK, let's go to the store and get some alcohol."  We jump on something that's sort of like a cross between a car and a motorcycle, and ride to Lucky's, the grocery store in town, but when we get there, all the lights are on and the windows are boarded up and we can't even get into the parking lot because it's been blocked.  Meghan was like "Oh, Lucky's is closed, you didn't know that?  It's late.  We have to go to Wal-Mart."  So I back up and turn around awkwardly, and begin making my way towards Wal-Mart, but the road is covered in construction equipment and dirt and all manner of crap, and I'm quite terrified; at some point I realize that I'm drunk.  I can't seem to maneuver the vehicle correctly.  I'm getting very scared.

Eventually I wind up at some place that's a cross between North Village and the Royal National Hotel in London.  Some quite attractive girl is sitting on the couch, crying, and I feel terribly awkward.  I ask her if she's OK, and said for her to let me know if there's anything I can do.  All of a sudden, I realize that it's not a girl at all, but a dude.  With a beard.  She says there's nothing I can do.  I wander into a bedroom, and there's a bowl of cereal sitting on a computer desk next to a computer.  I make myself a bowl of cereal, and I'm amused by the flatworm-shaped pieces inside the cereal.  I eat the cereal for a while, and wander back into the other room, where three other guys - supposedly the androgynous couch-weeper's roommates, and I introduce myself, and realize that I've wandered into a private residence.  They all don't seem to care; one of them points out that everyone in the room has a scruffy beard.  I continue eating my cereal, but then realize that some of the flatworm-shaped pieces are moving.  I recoil in disgust, realizing that I've been eating flatworms, and I start wanting to return to the computer to see what one should do in case of such an event, but there are huge, three-foot-long red glowing flatworms in the way, and they begin to attack me, constricting their bodies around mine.  This is TERRIFYING.  I begin to tear them apart, wondering if they will stop coming, but they keep on... I ask the guys in the apartment what I should do, and they tell me to just kill them.  They continue swarming all over me until finally I think I wake up, scared out of my mind.

I went back to sleep, though, and found myself at First Baptist Church in Knoxville, the church I grew up in, and for some reason I'm there with the improv troupe.  We're there to play some pranks.  I do all manner of wandering around, from floor to floor, wandering up and down the staircases.  Occasionally I see people, but I try to avoid them, because I don't feel like I'm supposed to be there.  Some strange music is coming from the hallway on the third floor.  All of a sudden, I realize that I'm unbelievably stoned, and movement has become next to impossible.  But I need water, so I make my way to the water fountain, avoiding eye contact with anyone.  The halls are dark.

Ian has set up some giant machine on the landing in one of the stairwells, a machine that will blow up an enormous number of balloons and then flood the room.  I'm not sure why we're doing this, but it's some sort of hilarious prank.  I feel bad; I don't want to do this to my old church, but I don't say anything... I just run upstairs when the machine goes on.  I hear keys on the fourth floor and duck away, because it's someone who's about to catch me!  Eventually, somehow I find the rest of the troupe, and they're in a small room with my roommate Andrew.  Some authority figure from the church shows up and chastises us viciously, and I feel terrible.  Andrew is pissed at all of us.

The end.

Turn off the lights, little one.
The bed crooks his broken finger.
There's more in dreams, little one,
More technicolor girls with fire eyes
That make your stomach vibrate.
And though they jump at you now
And flames drop from ducts to ignite the floor,
Turn the lights out, little one.
There's years left to you to dig
And excavate more alien skeletons
That dance with you in night hours,
That shake their hollow eyes
And squint at you in the dark.
You're picking at the wounds
And making new ones for her.
We taught you to think broadly
And cradle the souls around you.
Oh, your trembling limbs survive
And tremble away the sorrows.
Keep them to yourself, little one;
They are sharp metal in her brain.
With Jesus in your veins, keep bleeding.
Keep bleeding, little one,
And tremble away the sorrows.
Watch your friends dissolve in bottles,
As you become uninteresting
And dissolve in mason jars
While their eyes squint at you.

Turn the lights off, little one;
Her eyes will squint at you no more.
Keep your staggered breaths contained
And don't let your gasps in her ear.
With Jesus in your veins, keep bleeding.
Keep bleeding, little one,
And one day the technicolor girls will escape
And wrap you in blankets
And crawl into warmth with you.
Until then curl your toes under
And soak your pillows with memories
Of one short week when you forgot...
When you forgot your darkness,
When the world dissolved and there were only two,
And the lights came on and the paints were bright.

More writing, lyrics even this time, I'd post a goddamn mp3 if I could record vocals without people pounding on the walls because I'm too fucking loud.  Apartments.

I wish I had a studio so I could just pour myself into doing this, because it's what I want to do right now, it's what I need to do right now or I'm gonna 'splode.  Fuck some thin walls, fuck 'em.

_______________________________________________

I dream in orange, I bleed in colors no one knows
While you burrow tunnels deep in my chest
And our fingertips trace the hollow where we could live
The rain splashes in my eyes, leaking on your clothes

And oh, the canyons crack
And oh, the rivers wail
And oh, how you burn me when your breath sweeps through the room

I dream in colors, but my paint has dried and dulled and worn
While you splash bright pigment in my face
And our fingertips trace alien silhouettes
And black shadows breathe on us together

And oh, the canyons crack
And oh, the rivers wail
And oh, how my arms explode that they can't hold you

There's confusing, and then there's CONFUSING.

Up until nearly 6 am, but having the most fun I've had in a long time.  Serotonin levels jacked up like a mauhlfucka, I'm sure.  For some reason, I've remained energetic today, despite getting a scant 2 1/2 hours of sleep last night, and barely more than that the night before.

I'm feeling like an explosion lately.  I'm still frustrated as hell with Furman, with drug testing, and with bullshit, but everything else in my life seems to be going to well that that's just a sidenote, almost.  And yes, SEEMS to be going well; all the prospects for good news have yet to be confirmed, but that makes for an awfully exciting time, doesn't it?  An up-and-down kind of exciting, yes, but at least it's a feeling that makes me seem more alive than I usually do.

Ninfant be all fleshed out, and we've probably got a rehearsal space, and all that's gonna get kicked off really soon, which is exciting as all hell, and I'm ready (ohhh sooo ready) for that to happen.  Pretty much more excited about that than most things I could get excited about.

And girls are weird/exciting/wonderful/confusing.  Ones that hang out in your apartment until nearly six in the morning especially, though confusion certainly enters into it.  I just wish I had some clarity, that someone would come along and elucidate this situation.  Before last night, I just sensed a pending possibility, but after last night, I can't really keep my mind off of it.  People shouldn't be so much damn fun to be around.  It's otherworldly.

I just hope things sort themselves out in a manner that finds itself suitable to my own well-being, and my own sanity.  Plus I'm ready for karma to balance out from all the shit I've been through in the past month.  Everything looks like it's heading that way, and I'm keeping my fingers crossed, but I seem to get pretty vulnerable when I get my hopes up (Stratford, anyone?).  Of course, this is a bit more promising than THAT situation, but still...

So bizarre to be 21 and working on something you're pretty sure is going to be your masterpiece, your contribution to the world that'll probably stick out, what people will remember you for, etc.  Well, people who didn't know you very well, you know.  Strangers.  But King Juicebox is turning out to be everything we had planned.

If you like music, get psyched.  I think.

Life otherwise continues to be buttfuckingly confusing.  Girls with crushes, except the ones I'm fond of.  Pending fame (?).  Furman University trying to put my ass on ice.

Gon' be nice after I graduate, get me a li'l house up in Asheville or something, get me some girl to spend some time with, get Adam to come live up there, record a lot, play shows, put out the vibe...

Alright.

Man, beer.

You haven't had beer until you've been to Munich.  I swear.  The first night we were here, after an INSANE day of travel that included just BARELY catching the 10:43 train out of Paris (the doors nearly closed on Mary), we went to an Indian restaurant and ate some niiiice Indian food and ordered some beers... and we were all SO BLOWN AWAY.  It's like nothing I've ever had before.  Mmmmmm, beer.

Wintry, icy weather, and we're all staying in our cozy hostel room.  We had to move today into a different room, but this one actually has a private shower.  We're still just watching music videos all the time, hoping Snoop Dogg will make an appearance.  It's hard to figure out exactly what to do here.. we're so short on cash, and the weather is so nasty.  But it's fun, and Munich is really awesome.  The people are verrry nice, helping us with our pronounciation and stuff.  The first night, I learned how to count to ten in German by watching phone sex commercials, and I've added quite a few more numbers by watching the endless ringtone ads.  I could probably learn to speak the language pretty quickly if I were here for an extended period of time.  Especially if I had some books.  It hasn't been as much of a problem as I thought it would be, because most people speak English... but I'm trying to avoid that, and I'm using what little German I have whenever I can.  Knowing numbers helps... a lot.

Annnnnd I'm getting pretty lonely and homesick as well.  I miss people.  We're having a lot of fun, the three of us (though things got a bit strained yesterday)... but I miss people back in the US.  And my stuff.  Pretty eager to get back to my computer and my gee-tar and recording gear... and my family...

So we'll find something to do for the rest of the time we're here, and then it's off to have some crazzzzzzy adventures in Amsterdam.  I'm not looking forward to THAT at all, am I...

I told you... procrastination.

Anyway, 'Visiting Friends' was dripping down my skull and I was struck my a sudden momentary loneliness combined with a sedate complacency.  Despite me declaring my having nothing to look forward to, I have plenty to look forward to, and it's only my childish reluctancy to give up hope that keeps me moving forward.  I'm visiting Furman when I get back, meeting new people, maybe someone who I can lay in bed with and let some foreign music wash over us while we lay and define one another in muffled conversations stunted by timid make-out sessions that gradually grow in intensity.  Perhaps my visit will give me wonderful things to think about over Christmas break before I finally make my return to school, while Adam and I work on the Coffee Cantata II, and then the press blitz for the first Ninfant album, trying to make that cash back... Christmas itself, visiting my family, my friends back in Montevallo...  I try to keep a positive outlook.  Oh, and hey, New Year's should be brilliant as well.

I'm going to miss Europe though.  But hey, I've still got a few weeks.

Drifting around London with Sung Tongs on my iPod, letting the last vestiges of slight stoned-ness wisp away to the streets on my way to the Internet cafe to work on my damn project, which has the current problem of totally lacking direction.  Sung Tongs is glorious for sweeping through the streets of this city, though; its organic folkiness combined with that slight primeval pulse behind it provides quite a lovely contrast to the busy urban landscape, and creates a feeling of warm safetiness behind the hum.

I'm alarmingly content, even though events all around me in my life have been rather unfortunate lately to a degree; the election, of course, went horribly wrong, and I'm very much considering moving out of the US after I'm done at school, perhaps take a couple of years in Iceland or the UK, find something to do up here... I seem to like it better here anyway, and I just can't stay under another Bush administration.  I'm ashamed enough over here to have to admit to my nationality.  Blah blah blah John Paul you hate America... nope, I just hate what the country has become, what it's come to stand for now.  I couldn't be more opposed to what the country is now, the ideals it claims to hold dear.  Getting an outside perspective, though, really does show what a mess the US is in; inside the country everyone is blinded by patriotism, but once you're over here you see how terrible the US economy is and just how insane everyone thinks the US is... plus I don't think anyone notices how divided the US is right now, and Bush won't help that at all; he seems hellbent on further driving a wedge between the people.  A house divided...

Iceland was practically one of the best weekends of my life, despite an inappropriate and irresponsible amount of drinking... but when the Poisonous Dogs are flowing, who am I to stop them?  Adam and Helga and I and Helga's friends who refused to speak English traversed about the Icelandic countryside, to giant melting glacier waterfalls to blue, milky hot springs.  It was surreal, otherworldly, and completely wonderful.  Helga is clever, and is now promoting Ninfant up there with a couple of other people, and hopefully Adam and I wil be able to return this summer CHEAPLY to play some shows and hang out for a couple of weeks or so.  Wouldn't mind expatriating to Iceland for a few years, even... now I just have to get the hang of the damn language.

Alright, I should wrap this up and get back to work.

Well, yesterday was quite the bipolar whirlwind.  It began with Allison letting me know that I should stop and cease my ridiculous (non-)pursuit, and that she had been told that pretty explicitly.  Of course, I knew this would be the case, but it still served to completely deflate my resolve about everything, and I fell into a pretty deep nastiness.

So I wandered around Warwick castle with Allison talking out all of my qualms and problems and trying to make sense of my seemingly crumbling hope.  I tried to stay in good spirits, and I managed to be sort of OK.

After Warwick, we went to Kenilworth castle, where I along with some others, by climbing on the walls (an action we did not know was extremely illegal) got our group kicked out by some pissed-off ranger character.  

Get kicked out of a castle: check.

Fell asleep in my room, wallowing in my self-pity.  Ate dinner, and got somewhat buzzed off of the alcohol they served us, and wrote some pretty decent stuff on the ol' mandolin after that before progressing to our reading of Twelfth Night.  I read the part of Sir Andrew, which was great fun, and had more wine during the interval, managing to keep my character at a fair level of tipsyness.  I told [her] that I needed to talk to her at some point in an embarrassing and vulnerable manner, telling her she knew what I was talking out.

Several of us went to a bar after the reading, where we all sat and talked about religion and welfare and fun things like that.  We left bit by bit, and returned in the rain to the Quilt & Croissant, where [she] and I sat up in the hall, and I purged everything, told her everything I was thinking and feeling, in the hopes that that would clear my head and enable me to shift everything into platonic mode.  We talked for a while, moved on to other topics, and as I left I realized that my plan had pretty much worked... I was thinking of her much more in the sister-fashion than before, and I still am now.  I'm still quite full of affection for her, to be sure, but I wouldn't call it romantic affection now.

So THANK GOD.  Now my mind is at ease, and my ideal eventual partner has become alien for the first time in years.  It's kind of exciting, in a way.

In a way.

Today was pretty fantastic, as well... got a question-and-answer session with the phenomenal RSC actor Greg Hicks, who played Macbeth and Hamlet's Ghost, among other things.  We had all been hoping to talk to him, and we got to.  Fantastic.

This afternoon several of us went on a leisurely rowboat ride down the Avon river, after which I headed over here to the library, my final stop at the internet here.

Again, like the end of the tour, I feel like I've reached the end of another chapter, and now I shall move on into London with a different sense of security, and a different outlook on things.

It's funny that I feel all bipolar now that I'm on medication that is used in some instances to treat bipolarity.  But I suppose that's the effect.

I've been thinking a lot of course over the past few weeks, not only about the obvious things concerning romance and the like, but about my convictions, my religious/spiritual ideas, and the like.  Not calling anything into question, but strengthening what I trust.  How fascinating the world is.

Nothing is clear anymore.  Yesterday was a down day, today's looking up.  I wish I could control my own feelings, but I still haven't developed that superpower.  I'm working on it.

Writer's block is muh'fuckin' over though.  Hell yes.  I just hope my memory's up to the task of remembering a shitload of songs.

So yesterday hit a new low before it got better, just as soon as I finished yesterday's entry.  I decided to check on Leia via her journal, since I hadn't heard from her in a couple of days and was worried, and was treated to some of the most slanderous, offensive, hurtful, and infuriating things I've ever read.  This, needless to say, had me doing everything I could to fight back tears in the middle of the Stratford library, and was just blinded by how hurt, upset, and angry I was.  I don't know that I've ever felt that hurt by another person ever in my life, and man, that's just not much fun... so seeing the brilliant performance of Macbeth was halfway ruined because I couldn't focus on it.

Anyway, after the play, I just took a nihilistic walk around town, trying to settle myself down and ease my mind.  I felt more terrible than I've felt in a while, which was no fun...

Finally I went and ate dinner and felt a little better, then I went over to the other B&B to see if I could talk to [her] for a bit and just ease my mind some about everything, vent, etc.  So we ended up talking for quite a while, I felt much better, and then a bunch of us went dancing at this lame-ish club.  We didn't stay there for too long... I headed back to my room, sat up for a bit thinking and reading, listened to more XTC, and went to bed.

I'm really up and down in trying to figure out this situation right now.  Sometimes, like last night, I'm very, very convinced that what I want is in front of me and impossible (but maybe not TOTALLY impossible, if behavior is any indication), and sometimes I'm convinced that that's totally wrong.  I have so much going on in my head right now, and I think what I need more than anything is some comfort and assurance that eventually everything will work out everywhere.  My mind still settles and tells me to cry about Amanda on occasion, and I have to do that, to work through that.  I'm upset as I can be about Leia, on the many levels she's hurt me, and I wonder after what she's done now if we'll be able to regain some semblance of friendship.  I am willing to forgive, but it's going to take some apologizing.  I can't even express how that hurt me.

So now my hope is that there will be less confusion, and good things on the horizon.  For now, I'll just try to enjoy life to the fullest and not worry too much about things, even though my mind is a storm.

Man, what sort of insanity I live in.

And so now, I wind up completely fucking miserable.

A series of minor upsets and small things happening to me have brought the full weight of all the recent unpleasantries upon my back, and now it's breaking underneath it all. Really, the most striking thing is that I now have nothing concrete to look forward to; it's all just fantasy and etherea. With Leia's recent infidelity, I don't have my post-Europe visit to Austin to look forward to, and all the magic it was supposed to bring. Returning to Furman has just become something overwhelmingly terrifying, and my kidding myself that some ideal girl will be waiting for me there does nothing to pacify me. My current romantic situation, if you could even call it that, is a total and complete joke. So now I feel overwhelmingly alone, dejected, and ready to slough off my naive love for humanity and my naive hope for something good that's always kept me going.

To a degree, I feel useless and unwanted in any real sense. I obviously wasn't enough to keep Leia faithful. I'm not enough to capture the interest of those I'm interested in. I feel like I've returned to my inhuman state as entertainment. Sure, people care about me as a human, but that's only the view through the side window that's sort of weird and kind of fascinating. No one wants to stay there and get lost in its intricacies.

Romeo and Juliet was a disappointment. It lacked the whirlwind passion between the lovers that should be there, and without that, it's just a disappointment. That play should have made me weep like a child last night, and I didn't even feel the slightest twinge of sadness as a result of the play. I'm ready for that whirlwind, I want it... I could have done with watching a fake one onstage last night.

6.0.

I just want to capture someone, and have that person capture me, and be totally and completely enraptured so that we become blind to the rest of the world. Until she betrays me.

Shit.

Yesterday I did laundry with [her] and read The Waste Land while I waited for my stuff to dry. After [she] left, I was alone in the room and struck by how much I simultaneously loved and hated the world. Then I wrote this.

__________________________________________________________________

They were all in reverse and cracks in the plaster opposite
Their children ticked by counting the seconds
Recounting with glee the trivial minutae
Which after years mildewed
"Stomach to stomach," she sang
And I watched
Turtles fell into a turbine and eggshells came out
Thrum thrum thrum thrum thrum

* * *

Around and around and around they went
Letting the robots breathe on their faces.
So she knitted a quilt from the clothes I loved her in
And my toes traced the braille on the sides of her feet
I touched her face and it wrinkled
So she washed the quilt and touched an iron to my kneecaps
And the windows fogged, enthralled
Thrum thrum thrum thrum thrum

* * *

Cold it bled in but we didn't move
We just asked the trees to control us
But they blew in protest by the fences
And our arms jerked like marionettes.
After they swallowed the sun, they buried her on the mountain
So all the animals could visit
But they fenced up the valley to keep me out
Thrum thrum thrum thrum thrum
